summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office to Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal case. The Government argues for an earlier deadline for Maxwell to file a motion under Federal Rule of Evidence 412, which governs the admissibility of evidence about a victim's sexual behavior, to ensure proper review before trial.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (20 Cr. 330) who is seeking to file a motion under Federal Rule of Evidence 412 regarding victim evidence.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell case, to whom this government letter is addressed.

persons.name: Damian Williams
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York who submitted this letter to the court.

connections.description: Maxwell is the defendant in the criminal case over which Judge Nathan is presiding.
Williams, as U.S. Attorney, is leading the prosecution against defendant Maxwell.

events.title: Defendant's Letter to Court
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense counsel wrote to the court to confirm a November 15, 2021 deadline for filing a Rule 412 motion.

events.title: Government's Response Letter
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office filed this letter in response to the court's order and the defendant's letter, arguing for an earlier Rule 412 motion deadline.

events.title: Proposed Rule 412 Motion Deadline
events.description: The Court finds good cause for any Rule 412 motion to be filed by this date, as stated in the letter's introductory paragraph.

events.title: Tentative Hearing Date
events.description: The Court tentatively scheduled a hearing for this date regarding any Rule 412 motions.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
The Silvio J. Mollo Building, One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The Government is opposing the defense's proposed November 15, 2021 deadline for filing a Rule 412 motion, arguing the court has authority to set an earlier deadline.
Federal Rule of Evidence 412 restricts evidence about a victim's other sexual behavior to protect victim privacy, with exceptions that require a pretrial motion.
The Government argues an earlier deadline is needed to properly investigate and respond to sensitive Rule 412 issues and to hold necessary in camera hearings before trial.
The Government had already produced witness lists, Giglio material, Jencks Act material, and Rule 404(b) notice to the defense by October 11, 2021.
The document reveals the procedural timeline leading up to Maxwell's trial, including motion deadlines and hearing schedules.
